parameters: It's time to learn our next set of Hiragana
characters. There's 5 new characters to learn in this
I will go through each character individually and
teach you how to write it and pronounce it.
At the end of this chapter, we'll have a quiz, so
The characters we are learning in this lesson are
ta, chi, tsu, te and to. These characters follow our
pattern of a, i, u, e and o. But there's two exceptions
The first exception is 'chi', which starts with 'c'
instead of 't' and adds a soft 'h' sound.
The second exception is 'tsu', which adds an 's' sound
and is pronounced with less emphasis on the 't'.
You'll hear good examples of how to voice these
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
Tilt the top horizontal line properly.
The shape on the right is almost like a small こ, so
Get ready for the next character!
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
This character is made in just 2 strokes. Tilt the
horizontal line properly. Try not to confuse it with
さ (sa), which looks similar but is backwards.
Get ready for the next character!
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
single syllable. You pronounce this as 'tsoo'. The 't'
sound is very soft, like in 'tsunami'.
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
It's written in 1 stroke. Start with a fairly straight
line at the top, then curve accordingly.
Get ready for the next character!
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
Write this in one stroke. Start with a straight but
tilted line at the top, then curve it in as you go
Get ready for the next character!
It's a consonant followed by a vowel, and makes up a
Practice writing the character now. Some tips:
This character is written with two strokes. This
character looks good as long as the second line
That's it! We've finished this set of Hiragana.

Our friend, the dakuten, has returned!
This guy lets us change the sound of Hiragana.
We can use dakuten on our newly learned た series!
Adding dakuten to the characters we learned in this
lesson transforms the sound from 't' to 'd'.
I'll go through our 5 new characters and show you
what they become when you add dakuten.
Write た as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing だ in your notebook now.
You pronounce this as 'jee'. This character is an
exception in this set, as it's not a 'd' syllable.
And yes, it's the same sound as じ!
The character ぢ is not used commonly like じ.
So, when you need to write a word with a 'ji' sound,
always use じ unless you specifically know to use
Write ち as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing ぢ in your notebook now.
You pronounce this as 'zoo'. There's no 'd' sound for
And yes, it's the same sound as ず!
The character づ is not used commonly like ず.
So, when you need to write a word with a 'zu' sound,
always use ず unless you specifically know to use
Write つ as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing づ in your notebook now.
Write て as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing で in your notebook now.
Write と as normal, then add your dakuten marks in
the position shown in the image above.
Do you want me to pronounce it again?
Practice writing ど in your notebook now.
We've now finished this set! From this lesson, you've
learned a total of 10 new Hiragana!
